title: Investors pile into shares just before stock markets tumble
text:

Thu, Sep 3, 2015, 17:44 BST - UK Markets closed Investors pile into shares just before stock markets tumble By Kyle Caldwell | Telegraph – 1 hour 36 minutes ago 49.59 +3.11 
Equity fund sales hit a 15-year peak in July ahead of the stock market turbulence that has wiped 7.7pc from the FTSE 100 
Demand for investment funds hit its highest rate since April 2000 - the point at which the tech bubble popped - in July. 
Investors poured £2bn into equity funds during the month with those that buy UK-listed companies the best sellers, attracting £943m. 
European and global funds were also in vogue, taking in £532m and £338m respectively. 
Total (Swiss: FP.SW - news ) sales of unit trusts and Oeics stood at £3bn, the highest since April 2014, with Target Absolute Return and Property funds also proving popular, according to the industry figures from the Investment Association. 
The record sales have been put down to investors returning to the stock market having sold earlier this year ahead of the General Election. Investors took out £2.7bn from UK equity funds in the four months between January and April. 
The rush to invest was timed badly, as investors were soon hit with the steep fals in global stock markets that included "Black Monday" two weeks ago. 
The FTSE 100 has shed 7.7pc over the past month, with investors spooked by concerns of slowing economic growth in China. This afternoon the index was hovering just below the 6200 points mark. 
Daniel Godfrey, chief executive of the Investment Association, said: "Following investor hesitancy seen so far in 2015, confidence returned in July with the highest net retail sales for over a year. 
"Although it remains to be seen what impact August's volatility has on fund sales, retail investors had a strong appetite for equities in July, particularly UK equity funds which saw their highest net sales in over fifteen years."
